statement.text: Secondary lymphedema results from damage or obstruction of previously normal lymphatics, most commonly caused by cancer treatment (surgery, radiation, lymph node dissection), infection (filariasis worldwide, cellulitis in developed countries), or trauma, representing the vast majority of lymphedema cases globally.
statement.formal: Secondary_Lymphedema = Acquired_Lymphatic_Damage + (Surgery | Radiation | Infection | Trauma | Malignancy)

explanation.intuition: Unlike primary lymphedema where lymphatics form abnormally, secondary lymphedema starts with normal lymphatics that become damaged or blocked. The most common scenario in developed countries is after cancer treatment - removing lymph nodes or irradiating them destroys critical drainage pathways.
explanation.key_insight: Secondary lymphedema is far more common than primary lymphedema and is largely iatrogenic in developed countries. Breast cancer-related lymphedema affects 20-40% of patients after axillary lymph node dissection. Globally, filariasis causes over 120 million cases, making it the most common cause of lymphedema worldwide.
explanation.technical_details: Mechanisms of secondary lymphedema: (1) Surgical disruption - lymph node dissection removes drainage stations and severs collecting vessels; (2) Radiation fibrosis - damages lymphatic vessels and nodes, effects may be delayed years; (3) Tumor obstruction - direct invasion or compression of lymphatics; (4) Infection - filariasis causes lymphangitis and progressive fibrosis, recurrent cellulitis scars lymphatics; (5) Trauma - crush injuries, burns, or severe inflammation. Risk factors include extent of nodal dissection, radiation therapy, obesity, wound complications, and recurrent infections. Latency period can be months to decades after inciting event.

cancer_treatment.radiation: Direct lymphatic injury and delayed fibrosis
cancer_treatment.tumor_invasion: Direct obstruction of lymphatic channels or nodes
cancer_treatment.incidence: 20-40% after axillary dissection, 30% after groin dissection

infection.filariasis: Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia species - >120 million affected worldwide
infection.cellulitis: Recurrent episodes scar lymphatics; each episode worsens lymphedema
infection.tuberculosis: Lymph node involvement can obstruct drainage

other.CVI: Chronic venous insufficiency with secondary lymphatic overload

risk_factors: Extent of lymph node dissection (more nodes = higher risk)
Concurrent radiation therapy to regional nodes

presentation.timing: Days to decades after inciting event (median 1-3 years post-surgery)
presentation.complications: Cellulitis, lymphangitis, skin changes, rarely lymphangiosarcoma

staging_ISL.Stage_0: Latent - at risk but no visible edema
staging_ISL.Stage_II: Spontaneously irreversible - does not resolve with elevation, fibrosis
staging_ISL.Stage_III: Lymphostatic elephantiasis - severe fibrosis, skin changes

definition.@value: Lymphedema resulting from damage or obstruction of previously normal lymphatic vessels, most commonly from cancer treatment, infection, or trauma.

sources.title: Best Practice for the Management of Lymphoedema

learning_objectives: Identify the major causes of secondary lymphedema
Understand risk factors for cancer treatment-related lymphedema
Apply ISL staging to lymphedema patients
Recognize the global burden of filariasis-related lymphedema
clinical_pearls: 20-40% of patients develop lymphedema after axillary lymph node dissection
Sentinel node biopsy reduces but does not eliminate risk (5-7%)
Latency can be DECADES - counsel patients about lifelong risk
Each cellulitis episode worsens lymphedema - prevention is critical
Obesity doubles the risk - weight management is therapeutic
Filariasis causes 120+ million cases globally - most common cause worldwide
